instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2530: What is 820-2530? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.
definitions.U4900: What is U4900? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in older(pre-2013) macbooks.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PLT_RST_L: What is PLT_RST_L? This is an abbreviation of “PLT_RESET_L” – when you see “PLT_RST_L", assume the person meant to type PLT_RESET_L.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green Light, No Fan Spin
threads.message:
Hello,

I'm troubleshooting an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that consistently shows green light on charger but does not spin the fan.  I'm not quite sure what to test next and I'm hoping for some help.

I have 16.98v on pin 2 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> appears to be present, though that may be obvious because of the green light.  I'm attempting to walk through the troubleshooting logically rather than just trying to probe everything on the board.  To that end, I've looked through the forums and watched various videos on the subject too, but any specific next steps would be really helpful.

Steve

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green Light, No Fan Spin
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> appears to be present"
The exact voltage is very important to know!

This is an old machine, MCP could be dead, or close to its end life.
Post resistance to ground at <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> rail; measured on ohm scale.

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>1V05_S5</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green Light, No Fan Spin
threads.message:
Hello,

Thank you for the reply and it's good to be here (and not just lurking).

Specific voltage of <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> as measured at pin 2 of F7000 is 12.59V and 12.60V at pin 1 of <CAPACITOR>C7272</CAPACITOR> (near <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>) on the board.

I measured resistance to ground using pin 2 of <CHIP>U5000</CHIP> at received 2.566K; notably not sure if I am measuring that correctly for these boards.

Looking at <SIGNAL>1V05_S5</SIGNAL>, I receive 3.298V at pin 3 of <TRANSISTOR>Q3841</TRANSISTOR> but then 0.000V from pin 6.  If <TRANSISTOR>Q3841</TRANSISTOR> isn't producing 1.05V then that rail won't be created?

3V3S5 as measured at <SIGNAL>3V3S5_ENTRIP</SIGNAL> test point on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is 0.751V.  If I'm understanding the architecture correctly, that should be coming from <TRANSISTOR>Q7800</TRANSISTOR> which in turn comes from the SMC, <CHIP>U4900</CHIP>.  At test point <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> which comes from pin 119 on <CHIP>U4900</CHIP> and goes to pin 1 on <TRANSISTOR>Q7800</TRANSISTOR>, I read 3.416V.  Interestingly(?), trying to read <SIGNAL>PM_G2_P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL> coming from pin 3 on <TRANSISTOR>Q7800</TRANSISTOR> from its test point on the other side of the board, it is 0.00V.  And that's where I fall down: Knowing whether the voltage should make it through <TRANSISTOR>Q7800</TRANSISTOR> and on to pin 5 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> and whether or where the <SIGNAL>1V05_S5</SIGNAL> rail is actually created or should be present.

Looking at the schematics around <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, I am getting 4.952V on <SIGNAL>5V3V3S5_REG5</SIGNAL> from <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> and 3.388V on <SIGNAL>5V3V3_REG_EN</SIGNAL> (pin 13) on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>.

Your response caused me to relook at the schematics and rethink the flow of where rails are coming from, which is definitely some of what I was looking for.  Hopefully I can gain a better understanding of the architecture involved as we work through this.

Steve

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green Light, No Fan Spin
threads.message:
You still need time to understand the schematic; be patient, the practice will help.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is correct.

If <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is present, then <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> must be present too.
To avoid any misunderstanding, post <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> voltages; pins 16, 3, 13, 8, 17.
Use the surrounding components as test points, instead of chip pins.
Also <CHIP>U7750</CHIP>, pins 1, 2, 6, 8.

2.5K at <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is really bad; MCP seems to be dead in this case (more than 30K expected).
BTW, I was expecting that you catch L6995 as test point for <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>...

You can stil practice on this board, repairing <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>1V05_S5</SIGNAL> power supplies at least.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green Light, No Fan Spin
threads.message:
Hello,

<CHIP>U7200</CHIP>:
Pin 3 (<SIGNAL>5VS3_3V3S5_VREF</SIGNAL>), as measured using both/either of <CAPACITOR>C7271</CAPACITOR> or the test point near there, is 2.000V.
Pin 8 (<SIGNAL>5V3V3S5_REG3</SIGNAL>), as measured using <CAPACITOR>C7270</CAPACITOR> and the nearby test point, is 3.321V.
Pin 13 (<SIGNAL>5V3V3_REG_EN</SIGNAL>), as measured using <RESISTOR>R7273</RESISTOR> or the nearby test point,is 3.388V.
Pin 16 (<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>), as measured using <CAPACITOR>C7272</CAPACITOR>, is 12.59V.
Pin 17 (<SIGNAL>5V3V3S5_REG5</SIGNAL>), as measured using <CAPACITOR>C7273</CAPACITOR> or the nearby test point, is 4.952V.

<CHIP>U7750</CHIP>:
Pin 1 (<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>), measured using pin 2 of the nearby <TRANSISTOR>Q3810</TRANSISTOR>, is 3.320V.
Pin 2 (<SIGNAL>PM_G2_P1V05S5_EN</SIGNAL>), measured using both <CAPACITOR>C7801</CAPACITOR> and the nearby test point, is 3.414V.
Pin 6 (<SIGNAL>1V05S5_FB</SIGNAL>), measured on the other side of the board at <RESISTOR>R7781</RESISTOR>, is 0.815V.
Pin 8 (<SIGNAL>1V05S5_SW</SIGNAL>), measured using L7770 is 1.054V.  You mentioned that exact voltages matter, and this one seemed to slightly but noticeably move between 1.053 and 1.056V.  Both sides of L7770 report the same voltage.

For what it's worth, 3.419V at L6995.  Your note on this and the resistance measurement prompted me to re-measure resistance to ground using L6995 - much bigger pad.  The multimeter took a while but did climb above 30K, so I probably did measure that incorrectly yesterday.

The 2.00V on pin 3 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> caught me off-guard.  Guessing that VREF means "voltage reference" but I can't find a reference to 2V being used as a reference voltage in the schematic.  Is <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> just creating that VREF for its own use, like a feedback?  Ties to pin 14, through <CAPACITOR>C7271</CAPACITOR>, and then onward to ?    In any event, I checked L7220 and am receiving 3.329V on pin 1, jumping around between 3.315V and 3.329V.

Steve

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green Light, No Fan Spin
threads.message:
Post <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>RSMRST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> levels.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, at same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green Light, No Fan Spin
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> measured from the test point near <CAPACITOR>C4902</CAPACITOR> is 0.016V.  Is that the only place to measure it?

<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> measured on <RESISTOR>R2151</RESISTOR> is 0.001V.

<SIGNAL>RSMRST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R7840</RESISTOR> is 0.220V.

Triggered <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> across <RESISTOR>R5016</RESISTOR>, the power-on pads, and the voltage of <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> remained at 0.016V, with no indication of any change.

Steve

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green Light, No Fan Spin
threads.message:
All these signals must be steady high.
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> must drop only pressing <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>; which also must be high, rest of the time.

Check <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SM_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>.
Post all voltages for <CHIP>U7840</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green Light, No Fan Spin
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is 3.316V. 
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> is 3.401V.
<SIGNAL>SM_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> is 3.401V.

<CHIP>U7840</CHIP>:
Pin 1 <SIGNAL>RSMRST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 0.151V.
Pin 2 is GND.
Pin 3 <SIGNAL>P1V05_S5_PGOOD</SIGNAL> is 3.392V.
Pin 4 CT is 0.429V to 0.430V.
Pin 5 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is 3.320V.
Pin 6 is 3.419V.

I'm confused as to where to go next.  It seems like I'm missing something.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green Light, No Fan Spin
threads.message:
Be sure <RESISTOR>R7840</RESISTOR> is good.
If yes, change <CAPACITOR>C7841</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green Light, No Fan Spin
threads.message:
As would be expected, I don't have that cap, so I'll put together an order and probably get some of the 100K 1/16W resistors.  I have 402 package 1/10W, but I'm not sure if they're metal film or ceramic.  While I'm putting together the order are there other likely parts that I might need to replace - fully acknowledging that it's impossible to say for sure, but if something around this area is "common" then I'd like to get it on the same order.

Thanks for all of your help.

Steve

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green Light, No Fan Spin
threads.message: Get some MacBook scrap boards; is the best option for replacement parts...
